abstract.t: This specification describes how JCS combined with JWS , can be utilized to support HTTP based REST applications needing digitally signed requests. The described scheme is tailored for Web applications using JSON as message format. In addition, there is a specific variant for requests that do not have a HTTP body like GET.
The intended audiences of this document are Web tool vendors, as well as designers of secure Web applications.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Currently there is no standard for digitally signing REST requests. This has lead to the development of several proprietary solutions (see ) typically building on using HTTP header data for holding security constructs, while JSON request data is provided in clear in the HTTP body.

This specification is intended to provide a standardized alternative that fully honors the REST concept without (directly) using HTTP headers for holding security constructs. That is, JSON message data is supposed to also hold the security portion of a message. This arrangement has the following characteristics:
Since REST requests (as a minimum) also are defined by the HTTP URI and HTTP Verb these attributes are added as reserved JSON properties to the signed request data.
Due to the fact that messages compliant with this specification constitute of self-contained JSON objects, they may be serialized in databases or be embedded in other JSON objects. The latter includes supporting counter signatures.
The use of canonicalization provided by JCS makes signatures remain valid also after being processed by arbitrary JSON compliant tools.
JWS is used in detached mode without modifications or extensions.
For general interoperability concerns as well as due to the relyiance on JCS, JSON message data is limitied to the I&nbhy;JSON subset.
The above applies to REST requests using the HTTP methods POST, PUT or PATCH described in .
For REST requests using the HTTP methods GET or DELETE, another entirely URI based scheme is described in .

This specification presumes that JSON data ("payload") is expressed through a top level JSON Object.
The following subsections detail the operation for requests having an HTTP body.

section.title: Request Creation
section.t: For compliance with this specification the following properties MUST be be added to the JSON Object to be signed:

REQUIRED property holding the complete target URI.
REQUIRED property holding the HTTP method in uppercase.
OPTIONAL property holding a JSON object with HTTP headers related to the message. For more information see .
REQUIRED property holding a detached JWS signature calculated over the rest of the JSON payload using the method described in . Note that this property MUST be created and added after all other properties have been inserted in the JSON Object.
Since these property names are reserved they MUST NOT be used for other purposes in applications whishing to use this specification.

section.title: Request Validation
section.t:
In addition to normal validation of received data, the following steps MUST also be performed:
The arguments to "@rest.uri" and "@rest.verb" MUST be checked for correctness which usually only can be done by the service processing the request. If there is a mismatch the service MUST reject the request with an HTTP code 400 (malformed request).
The processing of the optional "@rest.headers" element is described in .
The signature provided in "@rest.signature" MUST be validated as described in .

section.title: Other Signed REST Solutions
section.t: This appendix briefly outlines a few other solutions addressing "Signed REST".

section.title: Amazon Web Services
section.t: Amazon Web Sevices provides a system for their clients using HTTP headers holding security constructs while the digested HTTP body may hold any valid media type. For more information see the . Signatures may also be added to query strings in a similar fashion to .

section.title: HTTP Signatures
section.t: HTTP Signatures is a system using HTTP headers holding security constructs while the (optional) digested HTTP body may hold any valid media type. This scheme has been adopted by the French Open Banking API . For more information see the Internet draft.

section.title: Open Banking (UK)
section.t:
The current (3.1) version of the Open Banking API use a scheme where a dedicated HTTP header holds a detached JWS signature covering a clear text JSON message in the HTTP body: POST /transact/pay HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Content-Type: application/json x-jws-signature: eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1N..SD7xMbpL-2QgwUsAlMGzw Content-Length: 2765
{ "something": "data",
Additional application specific properties
}

Notes:
The HTTP URI, method and headers are unsigned.
The signature argument (a JWS) was truncated for brevity.

section.title: Financial API
section.t:
The current version (Draft 06) of the financial API use a scheme where the payload is signed using JWS in Base64Url mode: POST /transact/pay HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Content-Type: application/jws Content-Length: 1288
eyJhbGcRjIn0.ew0KICJfds56gty5ypc3MiOiA.2QgwUsA565656lMGzw

Notes:
The HTTP URI, method and headers are unsigned.
The JWS signature was truncated for brevity.
